description: The adjective is borrowed from French brusque, from Italian brusco (“abrupt, sudden, brusque; brisk; eager; sour, tart; unripe; grim-looking”); further etymology unknown.
The verb is derived from the adjective.

adjectives.description: brusque (comparative brusquer or more brusque, superlative brusquest or most brusque)

verbs.description: brusque (third-person singular simple present brusques, present participle brusquing, simple past and past participle brusqued)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly archaic) To act towards (someone or something) in a curt or rudely abrupt manner.
